conclusion: To determine whether the distance fallen during the 10 to 15 seconds interval is greater than 75 meters or less than 75 meters, we need to analyze the velocity-time graph provided.
The x-axis represents time (t) in seconds. The y-axis represents velocity (v) in meters per second (m/s). The graph shows the velocity of the skydiver over time as he falls.
At t = 10 seconds, the velocity is 20 m/s. At t = 15 seconds, the velocity is 10 m/s. The velocity decreases linearly between these two points.

premise: The velocity decreases linearly between 10 and 15 seconds.
conclusion: The average velocity over the interval from 10 to 15 seconds can be calculated using the formula: Average velocity = (Final velocity + Initial velocity) / 2.
The distance fallen can be found by multiplying the average velocity by the time interval: Distance = Average velocity × Time interval.
The distance fallen during the 10 to 15 seconds interval is exactly 75 meters. Therefore, it is neither greater than 75 meters nor less than 75 meters; it is equal to 75 meters.
